questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic alcoholic patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Mallory-Denk bodies are a characteristic histopathological finding. These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions consist of aggregated cytoskeletal intermediate filaments, specifically prekeratin.

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

questions.text: In the presented spirometry image, what term corresponds to the point labelled as 'F'? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Forced vital capacity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The spirometry diagram illustrates various lung volumes and capacities –
  • • The spirometry diagram illustrates various lung volumes and capacities –
  • • The point labelled 'F' corresponds to the forced vital capacity (FVC), which is the maximum amount of air a person can forcibly exhale from their lungs after taking the deepest breath possible. It includes the tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV).
  • • In this context:
  • • In this context:
  • • Tidal Volume (TV): The amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing (A). Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation (B). Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): The additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation (C). Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): The total volume of air that can be exhaled forcefully after taking a deep breath (TV + IRV + ERV) (F).
  • • Tidal Volume (TV): The amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing (A).
  • • Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation (B).
  • • Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): The additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation (C).
  • • Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): The total volume of air that can be exhaled forcefully after taking a deep breath (TV + IRV + ERV) (F).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Expiratory reserve volume: This is the additional volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled after normal exhalation, represented by 'C' in the diagram.
  • • Option B. Expiratory reserve volume:
  • • Option C. Total lung capacity: This is the total volume of air in the lungs after a maximum inhalation, including the residual volume. It is not represented by 'F'.
  • • Option C. Total lung capacity:
  • • Option D. Inspiratory capacity: This is the total volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal exhalation, represented by 'D' in the diagram.
  • • Option D. Inspiratory capacity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spirometry diagram

questions.text: Assertion : Myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria. Reason : It is due to bacteremia. (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation of assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Assertion and reason are true but reason is not the correct explanation of assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true, reason is false

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is false, reason is true

questions.correct_answer: C. Assertion is true, reason is false
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The assertion that myocarditis is seen as a complication of diphtheria is correct. Myocarditis is a well-known and serious complication of diphtheria, often leading to significant morbidity and mortality.
  • • The reason provided, that myocarditis is due to bacteremia, is incorrect. The complications of diphtheria, including myocarditis, are primarily due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not bacteremia. The toxin affects various organs, including the heart, leading to myocarditis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myocarditis is a complication of diphtheria caused by the diphtheria toxin (toxemia), not by bacteremia.

questions.text: Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? ( INICET Nov 2020) Phenylephrine 1% Pilocarpine 0.1% Pilocarpine Cocaine 0.5% Epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: A woman presents with lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size, and appear pale. The histopathological image shows multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. The diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Molluscum contagiosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection that presents with dome-shaped papules containing Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are diagnostic of this condition.
  • ➤ Molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.

options.label: B
options.text: Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.

options.label: D
options.text: Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.correct_answer: B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year. But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.
  • ➤ In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • ➤ But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes: (NEET PG 2020
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cardiovascular diseases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The scope of Project MONICA is focused on cardiovascular diseases, specifically monitoring trends in coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease and examining the impact of various risk factors on these conditions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester has a 2-year-old child. She received a complete vaccination course during her last pregnancy. What tetanus immunization is recommended for her now? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Td booster dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pregnant women who received the complete Td vaccination course during their last pregnancy within the last three years, a Td booster dose is recommended.

questions.text: 15-year-old patient presents with abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. CRP and ESR were elevated, and urinalysis showed RBCs. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IgA vasculitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) commonly presents with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain, and renal involvement, and is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anovulation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Endometriosis : Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.
  • • Option B. Endometriosis
  • • Option C. Malignancy : Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.
  • • Option C. Malignancy
  • • Option D. Bleeding disorder : Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.
  • • Option D. Bleeding disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

options.label: B
options.text: Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa

options.label: C
options.text: Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.correct_answer: A. Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 504, 505
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 504, 505

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Immediate pharmacological treatment for hypertension in patients without additional cardiovascular risk factors or organ damage should commence when blood pressure levels exceed 160/100 mmHg, according to the ISH 2020 guidelines. This approach helps to target treatment to those most likely to benefit from immediate intervention, balancing the benefits and risks of pharmacotherapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: D
options.text: Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

questions.text: A man eats 3 cones of ice cream. After some time, he starts feeling more colder ears than the central parts of his body. Which part of the brain is responsible for thermo-regulation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypothalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypothalamus is the part of the brain responsible for regulating body temperature and maintaining homeostasis.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exudative pleural effusions are typically caused by conditions that involve inflammation or injury to the pleura, such as rheumatoid arthritis, while transudative effusions are usually due to systemic conditions like heart failure, liver failure, and nephrotic syndrome that affect hydrostatic or oncotic pressure.

questions.text: There was outbreak of MRSA in the hospital, and it was found that a nurse of NICU had MRSA colonization of anterior nares. What is the best treatment?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Topical mupirocin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For MRSA colonization in the anterior nares, topical mupirocin is the best treatment due to its targeted action, efficacy, and minimal systemic side effects.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: - KDT 8 TH /809

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis
  • ➤ clinical
  • ➤ verrucous skin
  • ➤ histopathological finding
  • ➤ sclerotic or copper penny
  • ➤ dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia

options.label: B
options.text: Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.correct_answer: C. Prevention of RDS in premature baby
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):
  • • Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):
  • • MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:
  • • Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.
  • • Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  • • Eclampsia:
  • • Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  • • Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia:
  • • Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  • • Tocolytic in Preterm Labor:
  • • Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.
  • • Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks):
  • • Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:
  • • Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:
  • • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.
  • • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  • • Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia:
  • • Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.
  • • Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia:
  • • Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.
  • • Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corticosteroids are used for the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm babies.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who is eagerly drinking water and skin pinch goes back slowly. Which category does the child belong according to IMNCI? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yellow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the IMNCI color coding system:
  • ➤ Green indicates no dehydration. Yellow indicates some dehydration. Pink indicates severe dehydration.
  • ➤ Green indicates no dehydration.
  • ➤ Yellow indicates some dehydration.
  • ➤ Pink indicates severe dehydration.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AV fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 166
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intellectual disability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's essential to understand that the term "mental retardation" is now outdated and has been replaced with "intellectual disability" in clinical settings, especially according to DSM-5, to ensure respectful and non-stigmatizing communication.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1118-1119.

questions.text: What is the most common anemia in a 65-year-old female? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia in a 65-year-old female, with causes shifting from menstrual blood loss in younger women to chronic gastrointestinal blood loss (due to malignancies) and nutritional deficiencies in the elderly.

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Type 2 lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is mediated by a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of reaction:
  • • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation. This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies. The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation. Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity: Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens). Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation. Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • • This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies.
  • • The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation.
  • • Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • • Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens).
  • • Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation.
  • • Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:
  • • Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:
  • • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation. Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).
  • • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation.
  • • Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).
  • • Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:
  • • Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:
  • • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity). Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.
  • • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • • Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.
  • • Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:
  • • Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:
  • • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages. Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation. Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.
  • • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • • Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation.
  • • Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition. It presents with tender nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation and is commonly associated with lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of cancer? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: It acts as an alkylating agent

options.label: D
options.text: It inhibits polymerization of tubulin monomers in mitosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate exerts its anticancer effects primarily by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, thereby blocking the synthesis of DNA and RNA necessary for cell replication.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of burning sensation during urination and a purulent discharge from the penis for the past 5 days. He has had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. On examination, the urethral meatus is erythematous, and there is a noticeable purulent discharge. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no known drug allergies. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 Million Units intramuscularly

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg orally

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cefixime 400 mg orally is an effective oral treatment option for gonorrhea, particularly in patients who prefer to avoid injections. The presence of intracellular gram-negative diplococci in a symptomatic patient strongly suggests gonococcal infection, requiring prompt and appropriate antibiotic therapy.
  • ➤ Cefixime 400 mg orally

questions.text: A gymnasium owner found that people drank ice tea while exercising in his gym. He further mentioned that the subsequent weight loss was solely due to ice tea. This is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A spurious association occurs when a relationship is wrongly inferred between two variables due to a confounding factor. In this case, the gym owner incorrectly attributed weight loss to ice tea consumption rather than the true cause, which is exercise.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone. Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.
  • ➤ The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • ➤ Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

questions.text: Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis? Triangular obturator foramen U-shaped pubic angle Everted ischial tuberosity Large greater sciatic notch Large acetabulum Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differences between male and female pelvis
  • ➤ Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? ( INICET MAY 2022) Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h Start injection ceftriaxone Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is inhalational anesthetic of choice for pediatric age group? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sevoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational anesthetic for pediatric patients due to its rapid onset, pleasant odor, and favorable safety profile. It is particularly useful for inhalational induction, making it easier for children to tolerate the induction process.
